content: How can I help you today?

Well, my wife and I are going through a really rough patch at home because of our son. He’s been acting out, and we can’t seem to figure out what he needs or how to help him. It’s taking a toll on me—I’m struggling at work, I can’t enjoy anything, and I honestly feel like my marriage might fall apart.

That sounds incredibly overwhelming and painful. It seems like you’re carrying a lot—the stress of parenting, the strain on your marriage, and the weight it’s placing on your own well-being. It takes courage to open up about these challenges. How have you been navigating all of this so far?

I’m not sure I’ve been navigating it at all. I’ve mostly been shutting down, if I’m honest. I just feel so stuck, like nothing I do will make a difference, and I don’t even know where to start. It’s easier to avoid dealing with it, but then it all feels worse.

It's understandable that you're feeling stuck right now. It sounds like avoiding these struggles might feel like a temporary relief, but it also adds to the weight you're carrying over time. That feeling of not knowing where to start can be incredibly daunting, especially when everything feels so interconnected. What do you wish could be different, either for yourself or for your family?

I wish I could just feel like I’m helping my son instead of failing him. I want my wife and I to be on the same page again and not constantly arguing. And I want to be able to focus, at least a little bit, on my daughter and on living a life that doesn’t feel so heavy. I just don’t know how to make any of that happen.

It’s clear how deeply you care about your son, your wife, and your family as a whole. You want to support them and find harmony again, and that shows so much strength and love, even when things feel so heavy right now. It also sounds like you’re longing to shift some of this weight off yourself, to breathe a bit and reconnect with the things that matter to you. What do you think has been the biggest barrier to reaching that place for you?

I think the biggest barrier is just feeling overwhelmed, like there’s too much all at once, and I don’t even know which problem to tackle first. On top of that, I don’t feel like I have the energy or clarity to figure out what’s right. It’s just been exhausting.

Feeling overwhelmed can make everything seem impossible to tackle, especially when energy and clarity feel so out of reach. And exhaustion like that can make even small steps seem too much. That’s a lot to bear, and it makes sense why it’s been hard to find a starting point. If things felt more manageable, what do you think would be most important for you to focus on first?

It would probably be figuring out how to help my son. If we could understand what’s going on with him and help him improve, maybe the tension between my wife and me would ease up too. I feel like everything hinges on that, but I don’t even know where to begin.

It sounds like helping your son is really central to how you’re envisioning a way forward, not just for him, but for your family as a whole. That hope you have to understand him and make things better shows just how deeply you’re invested in his well-being. It’s understandable that not knowing where to start feels discouraging. How do you think focusing on him might positively impact your relationship with your wife or create more balance in your family?

I think it would take some of the stress off my relationship with my wife if we weren't constantly trying to figure out how to handle him without success. If we could be united in helping him and actually see some progress, it might remind us that we're on the same team. Plus, it would let us focus a bit more on my daughter and maybe even reconnect as a couple. But I have no idea how to start that process.

Your hope for unity with your wife, progress for your son, and balance within your family shows incredible care and insight. It's clear how deeply these connections matter to you. It sounds like finding a way to approach your son’s needs together might ease some tension and open space for those other important areas, like your daughter and your marriage. If you were to take one small step toward understanding or helping your son, what might that look like for you?

Maybe seeking advice from someone who specializes in behavioral health could be a start, but honestly, I feel hesitant about that. It’s hard to imagine someone from the outside really understanding what we’re dealing with, and I’d feel kind of exposed. But I guess… maybe it could be helpful if it means getting some answers for him and moving forward?

Seeking advice from a behavioral health specialist could feel vulnerable, especially when you’re unsure how someone from outside might understand your situation—that hesitation makes a lot of sense. At the same time, you’re showing openness to the idea because of how much you want answers for your son and a path forward for your family. It might be a step toward the teamwork and clarity you’re hoping for. What would make it feel more comfortable or doable for you to explore that option?

Maybe if my wife and I went together and approached it as a team, it might feel less intimidating. I’d feel more supported, and maybe we’d both learn how to better help our son. I’m still nervous about it, but it’s starting to seem like it might be worth a try.

Going together as a team sounds like a thoughtful way to feel supported and build unity with your wife while tackling this together. That sense of partnership could help ease some of the nerves and create a shared understanding for how to help your son. Your willingness to consider this step, even with hesitation, shows how committed you are to your family. Is there anything else about this idea—or about your situation—that you’d like to talk through?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
